Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Biventricular Pacing on Hemodynamics Post-Cardiopulmonary Bypass

Trial_Design.evidence: Patients were randomised to receive either optimized biventricular pacing or atrial pacing at a matched heart rate

Participants.evidence: 30 patients with a mean ejection fraction of 35%±15% and mean QRS duration of 119±24 ms undergoing coronary bypass and/or valve surgery were included

Intervention.evidence: Patients were randomised to receive either optimized biventricular pacing or atrial pacing at a matched heart rate

Objective.evidence: This study evaluates its sustained effects on mean arterial pressure (MAP) post-chest closure

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the change in MAP, measured over 30-second intervals

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was conducted using a computer-generated sequence, and allocation was concealed

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was applied to outcome assessors

Number_Randomised.evidence: 30 patients with a mean ejection fraction of 35%±15% and mean QRS duration of 119±24 ms undergoing coronary bypass and/or valve surgery were included

Result_Outcome.evidence: Optimized biventricular pacing increased MAP by 4% compared to sinus rhythm (78.5±2.4 vs 75.1±2.4 mm Hg; P=0.002) and by 3% compared to atrial pacing (76.4±2.7 mm Hg; P=0.017)
